title: USDA relocation plan has top NIFA staff competing for handful of D.C. jobs
content:
USDA has said the relocation will save taxpayer dollars and bring the agencies closer to major farming regions. | Saul Loeb/AFP/Getty Images Agriculture USDA relocation plan has top NIFA staff competing for handful of D.C. jobs

The Trump administration's plan to move the National Institute of Food and Agriculture out of Washington has created a cutthroat competition among high-level staffers for a limited number of non-relocation positions that employees liken to a "Hunger Games"-like environment.

Some 70 national program leaders — top positions within NIFA that oversee research areas from forestry to nutrition — are faced with competing for just six national program leader jobs that will remain in D.C., according to interviews with several current and former agency staffers and a copy of a document USDA officials shared with employees detailing the positions that will be required to relocate.

Story Continued Below

Just 20 positions agency-wide will be kept in Washington to maintain “D.C.-centric functions,” such as interacting with lawmakers and government and industry officials, the department said in the document. All other NIFA positions — a number USDA pegs at 315 jobs — will be based in the agency's new headquarters, a site for which is expected to be announced shortly.

Of the 20 positions that will be Washington-based, staffing for the six national program leader jobs will be determined by a “competitive process” in which employees will have to submit formal applications, according to the document.

Multiple national program leaders told POLITICO that Agriculture Department leadership has reassured them that no one will lose their job if they don't land one of the Washington posts.

But the employees said they are anxious about what their positions would entail if they are relocated. They said they feel like they've been left in the dark about how the application process will be conducted and what the timeline will be. And they said they believe the process will contribute to a spike in departures that has rippled through the agency since Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue unveiled the relocation plan in August.

“You would not believe the emotional distress people are going through," one of the employees told POLITICO, requesting anonymity for fear of reprisal. "They’re losing sleep, getting sick, medical conditions are exacerbated by this.”

Employees now commonly use "Hunger Games" as a shorthand for the competition that awaits them — a reference to a science fiction book in which children are selected to compete to the death for entertainment.

NIFA workers didn't learn that select employees would be allowed to stay in Washington until a staff-wide meeting in March — or seven months after Perdue announced the relocation proposal, staffers told POLITICO. Following that meeting, "people were left with a lot of questions and a lot of bewilderment about what this is going to do to us,” said another NIFA employee granted anonymity due to their fear of retaliation.

Employees said their unease over the pending move is made worse by the fact that the application process remains uncertain more than three months after the staff-wide meeting.

The department's decision to have national program directors vie for Washington-based jobs “starts pitting people against each other who have worked together for decades," said Sonny Ramaswamy, a former NIFA director during the Obama administration who has been outspoken against the relocation.

“It is the most pathetic thing to do,” he said.

NIFA has the primary responsibility of funneling USDA grants for projects to land-grant universities across the country. As the liaison between land-grant universities and the federal government, the agency coordinates regional research projects involving multiple academic institutions.

Perdue's plan to revamp the department's research wing would relocate NIFA along with the Economic Research Service. The proposal has been criticized by current and former agency staffers, who say morale has taken a huge hit, and by a number of lawmakers, mostly Democrats.

The House's fiscal 2020 spending bill for USDA, which cleared the Appropriations Committee earlier this week, includes language that would block Perdue from relocating the agencies and from implementing another part of the plan — bringing ERS under the control of the Office of the Chief Economist, where some argue it would be more open to direct influence from the Office of the Secretary. But it is unlikely the spending bill will become law before the department begins the final part of the relocation process.

Much of the criticism of the plan has focused on the department's motivations for relocating ERS staff and for the potential for its research to be politicized. A number of current and former agency employees previously told POLITICO they believe the move is an effort to silence research that could make the White House look bad.

A USDA spokesperson confirmed the department recently told NIFA and ERS employees how the reorganized agencies would operate — and stressed that communication with staff is a priority.

"As part of our vision to make USDA the most efficient, most effective and most customer-focused department in the federal government, USDA recently shared information with NIFA and ERS employees describing the proposed functionality of each agency which has been determined to remain within the National Capital Region versus the functionality that will be re-located," a USDA spokesperson said in a statement to POLITICO.

"Currently, USDA’s highest priority regarding the relocation is communicating with our employees. As there is additional information to share with the public, USDA remains committed to doing so," the statement added.

But employees warn that relocating NIFA will compromise the agency's ability to efficiently get research funds out the door. And they're worried that the move and the competitive process for the Washington-based jobs could contribute to people leaving USDA and create a brain drain of research knowledge that has already started to become apparent at ERS, where six economists left on the same day earlier this year.

NIFA employees are set to vote next week on whether to unionize. ERS staff voted to form a union last month.

USDA has said the relocation will save taxpayer dollars and bring the agencies closer to major farming regions. The department has narrowed the site selection process to the greater Kansas City area, North Carolina‘s Research Triangle Park and multiple locations in Indiana.

Perdue, in Raleigh, N.C., earlier this week, told a local news outlet that employees “have been vocal, obviously; but anytime you make change and you move people’s cheese, there’s always anxiety.”

Scientists inside and outside NIFA said they’re worried that taking the bulk of the agency away from Washington could also lower its profile among congressional appropriators and as a result lead to decreased funding levels.

There’s also widespread concern among researchers in academia that institutions near the new home of NIFA could be disadvantaged when applying for USDA funding by the department's effort to guard against the appearance of bias.

Linda Prokopy, a professor of natural resources and social science at Purdue University, said she's rooting for Indiana to not be selected because she believes it would reduce her chances of getting funded.

"They're going to bend over backwards to demonstrate that they're not biased and I don't think that's going to be good for whoever is in that final location," she said.

title: EPA may take Salt Lake off its dirty-air list, thanks partly to the weather
content:
After 13 years, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency is poised to remove the Salt Lake metro region from its list of areas that violate its 24-hour pollution standards for fine particulates.

That’s partly because the state has made efforts to reduce its emissions — Utah’s Air Quality Board has passed more than 20 regulations to reduce industry emissions — and partly because Utah has been, well, lucky.

“Luck is a big part of this,” said Thom Carter, executive director of the Utah Clean Air Partnership, or UCAIR. “Remember, our air-quality problem starts as a weather issue. It all has to do with inversion.”

And temperature inversions, which trap dirty air in the Salt Lake Valley, were less severe from 2016 through 2018. The EPA made the proposal to change the region’s designation based on air-quality monitoring from that three-year period, which showed the area did not exceed the standard for the first time since it was established in 2006.

(The Salt Lake region includes all of Salt Lake and Davis counties and parts of Box Elder, Tooele and Weber counties.)

Just two years ago, the EPA classified the Salt Lake region as a “serious” nonattainment area.

“We’ve reduced our emissions significantly over this period of time,” Carter said. “Additionally, we’ve had great weather patterns in the last three years. But if we go a long time between storms in the wintertime, then we will exceed the limit.”

This is not a case of Salt Lake coming into compliance because the standards were lowered. Actually, when the policy was instituted in 2006, it was for PM10 particulates — a standard that has since been changed to the more stringent PM2.5, measuring particulates one-quarter the size of PM10.

The monitoring averages PM2.5 particulates across 24-hour periods, so the levels could still exceed the standard at times and be in compliance. The EPA’s rules allow an area to exceed the limits for approximately 21 days over the course of three years.

PM2.5 refers to particulates that are 2.5 microns or less in width; the largest are about 30 times smaller than the width of a human hair. They reduce visibility and cause the air to appear hazy when levels are elevated.

Short-term health effects include eye, nose, throat and lung irritation, coughing, sneezing, runny nose and shortness of breath. Long term, the fine particulates can affect lung function and worsen asthma and heart disease.

Article continues below

Carter pointed to the billions and billions of dollars invested by mining companies and oil refineries to install the “best available technologies” to control their emissions as one reason the PM2.5 levels have fallen. He said individual Utahns have helped, too.

“We’ve seen in our own personal data where people are saying they’re car pooling more than they’ve ever carpooled. They’re not idling as much. They’re trip-chaining,” he said. “People are better aware of their own emission space, and they’re finding ways to be part of the solution.”

Not all Utahns, however, according to a Salt Lake Tribune-Hinckley Institute of Politics poll conducted in January. It indicated about a third of those surveyed had changed their commuting habits to improve air quality.

The change in designation is not yet a done deal. The EPA posted its proposal on the Federal Register on Wednesday; a 30-day period for comments runs through July 5. Comments can be submitted to regulations.gov, identified by docket ID No. EPA-R08-OAR-2019-0081.

Even if it is finalized, it’s not necessarily a permanent change. Monitoring will continue, and Salt Lake City could end up back on the noncompliant list.

“Today is a day for everybody to shake hands and say, 'Congratulations, we've achieved something,'” Carter said. “But this is step one. We're nowhere near being done. And anybody who thinks we're done is crazy.
